5252static void __maybe_unused unthrottle_offline_cfs_rqs(struct rq *rq)
5253{
5254 struct task_group *tg;
5255
5256 lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
5257
5258 rcu_read_lock();
5259 list_for_each_entry_rcu(tg, &task_groups, list) {
5260 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = tg->cfs_rq[cpu_of(rq)];
5261
5262 if (!cfs_rq->runtime_enabled)
5263 continue;
5264
5265 /*
5266 * clock_task is not advancing so we just need to make sure
5267 * there's some valid quota amount
5268 */
5269 cfs_rq->runtime_remaining = 1;
5270 /*
5271 * Offline rq is schedulable till CPU is completely disabled
5272 * in take_cpu_down(), so we prevent new cfs throttling here.
5273 */
5274 cfs_rq->runtime_enabled = 0;
5275
5276 if (cfs_rq_throttled(cfs_rq))
5277 unthrottle_cfs_rq(cfs_rq);
5278 }
5279 rcu_read_unlock();
5280}
5281
5282#else /* CONFIG_CFS_BANDWIDTH */
5283static inline u64 cfs_rq_clock_task(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
5284{
5285 return rq_clock_task(rq_of(cfs_rq));
5286}
5287
5288static void account_cfs_rq_runtime(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, u64 delta_exec) {}
5289static bool check_cfs_rq_runtime(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) { return false; }
5290static void check_enqueue_throttle(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) {}
5291static inline void sync_throttle(struct task_group *tg, int cpu) {}
5292static __always_inline void return_cfs_rq_runtime(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) {}
5293
5294static inline int cfs_rq_throttled(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
5295{
5296 return 0;
5297}
5298
5299static inline int throttled_hierarchy(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
5300{
5301 return 0;
5302}
5303
5304static inline int throttled_lb_pair(struct task_group *tg,
5305 int src_cpu, int dest_cpu)
5306{
5307 return 0;
5308}
5309
5310void init_cfs_bandwidth(struct cfs_bandwidth *cfs_b) {}
5311
5312#ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
5313static void init_cfs_rq_runtime(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq) {}
5314#endif
5315
5316static inline struct cfs_bandwidth *tg_cfs_bandwidth(struct task_group *tg)
5317{
5318 return NULL;
5319}
5320static inline void destroy_cfs_bandwidth(struct cfs_bandwidth *cfs_b) {}
5321static inline void update_runtime_enabled(struct rq *rq) {}
5322static inline void unthrottle_offline_cfs_rqs(struct rq *rq) {}
5323
5324#endif /* CONFIG_CFS_BANDWIDTH */
5325
5326/**************************************************
5327 * CFS operations on tasks:
5328 */
5329
5330#ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_HRTICK
5331static void hrtick_start_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
5332{
5333 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
5334 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
5335
5336 SCHED_WARN_ON(task_rq(p) != rq);
5337
5338 if (rq->cfs.h_nr_running > 1) {
5339 u64 slice = sched_slice(cfs_rq, se);
5340 u64 ran = se->sum_exec_runtime - se->prev_sum_exec_runtime;
5341 s64 delta = slice - ran;
5342
5343 if (delta < 0) {
5344 if (rq->curr == p)
5345 resched_curr(rq);
5346 return;
5347 }
5348 hrtick_start(rq, delta);
5349 }
5350}
5351
5352/*
5353 * called from enqueue/dequeue and updates the hrtick when the
5354 * current task is from our class and nr_running is low enough
5355 * to matter.
5356 */
5357static void hrtick_update(struct rq *rq)
5358{
5359 struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
5360
5361 if (!hrtick_enabled(rq) || curr->sched_class != &fair_sched_class)
5362 return;
5363
5364 if (cfs_rq_of(&curr->se)->nr_running < sched_nr_latency)
5365 hrtick_start_fair(rq, curr);
5366}
5367#else /* !CONFIG_SCHED_HRTICK */
5368static inline void
5369hrtick_start_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
5370{
5371}
5372
5373static inline void hrtick_update(struct rq *rq)
5374{
5375}
5376#endif
5377
5378/*
5379 * The enqueue_task method is called before nr_running is
5380 * increased. Here we update the fair scheduling stats and
5381 * then put the task into the rbtree:
5382 */
5383static void
5384enqueue_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
5385{
5386 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
5387 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
5388
5389 /*
5390 * The code below (indirectly) updates schedutil which looks at
5391 * the cfs_rq utilization to select a frequency.
5392 * Let's add the task's estimated utilization to the cfs_rq's
5393 * estimated utilization, before we update schedutil.
5394 */
5395 util_est_enqueue(&rq->cfs, p);
5396
5397 /*
5398 * If in_iowait is set, the code below may not trigger any cpufreq
5399 * utilization updates, so do it here explicitly with the IOWAIT flag
5400 * passed.
5401 */
5402 if (p->in_iowait)
5403 cpufreq_update_util(rq, SCHED_CPUFREQ_IOWAIT);
5404
5405 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
5406 if (se->on_rq)
5407 break;
5408 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
5409 enqueue_entity(cfs_rq, se, flags);
5410
5411 /*
5412 * end evaluation on encountering a throttled cfs_rq
5413 *
5414 * note: in the case of encountering a throttled cfs_rq we will
5415 * post the final h_nr_running increment below.
5416 */
5417 if (cfs_rq_throttled(cfs_rq))
5418 break;
5419 cfs_rq->h_nr_running++;
5420
5421 flags = ENQUEUE_WAKEUP;
5422 }
5423
5424 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
5425 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
5426 cfs_rq->h_nr_running++;
5427
5428 if (cfs_rq_throttled(cfs_rq))
5429 break;
5430
5431 update_load_avg(cfs_rq, se, UPDATE_TG);
5432 update_cfs_group(se);
5433 }
5434
5435 if (!se)
5436 add_nr_running(rq, 1);
5437
5438 hrtick_update(rq);
5439}
5440
5441static void set_next_buddy(struct sched_entity *se);
5442
5443/*
5444 * The dequeue_task method is called before nr_running is
5445 * decreased. We remove the task from the rbtree and
5446 * update the fair scheduling stats:
5447 */
5448static void dequeue_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int flags)
5449{
5450 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
5451 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
5452 int task_sleep = flags & DEQUEUE_SLEEP;
5453
5454 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
5455 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
5456 dequeue_entity(cfs_rq, se, flags);
5457
5458 /*
5459 * end evaluation on encountering a throttled cfs_rq
5460 *
5461 * note: in the case of encountering a throttled cfs_rq we will
5462 * post the final h_nr_running decrement below.
5463 */
5464 if (cfs_rq_throttled(cfs_rq))
5465 break;
5466 cfs_rq->h_nr_running--;
5467
5468 /* Don't dequeue parent if it has other entities besides us */
5469 if (cfs_rq->load.weight) {
5470 /* Avoid re-evaluating load for this entity: */
5471 se = parent_entity(se);
5472 /*
5473 * Bias pick_next to pick a task from this cfs_rq, as
5474 * p is sleeping when it is within its sched_slice.
5475 */
5476 if (task_sleep && se && !throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq))
5477 set_next_buddy(se);
5478 break;
5479 }
5480 flags |= DEQUEUE_SLEEP;
5481 }
5482
5483 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
5484 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
5485 cfs_rq->h_nr_running--;
5486
5487 if (cfs_rq_throttled(cfs_rq))
5488 break;
5489
5490 update_load_avg(cfs_rq, se, UPDATE_TG);
5491 update_cfs_group(se);
5492 }
5493
5494 if (!se)
5495 sub_nr_running(rq, 1);
5496
5497 util_est_dequeue(&rq->cfs, p, task_sleep);
5498 hrtick_update(rq);
5499}
5500
5501#ifdef CONFIG_SMP
5502
5503/* Working cpumask for: load_balance, load_balance_newidle. */
5504DEFINE_PER_CPU(cpumask_var_t, load_balance_mask);
5505DEFINE_PER_CPU(cpumask_var_t, select_idle_mask);
5506
5507#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
5508/*
5509 * per rq 'load' arrray crap; XXX kill this.
5510 */
5511
5512/*
5513 * The exact cpuload calculated at every tick would be:
5514 *
5515 * load' = (1 - 1/2^i) * load + (1/2^i) * cur_load
5516 *
5517 * If a CPU misses updates for n ticks (as it was idle) and update gets
5518 * called on the n+1-th tick when CPU may be busy, then we have:
5519 *
5520 * load_n = (1 - 1/2^i)^n * load_0
5521 * load_n+1 = (1 - 1/2^i) * load_n + (1/2^i) * cur_load
5522 *
5523 * decay_load_missed() below does efficient calculation of
5524 *
5525 * load' = (1 - 1/2^i)^n * load
5526 *
5527 * Because x^(n+m) := x^n * x^m we can decompose any x^n in power-of-2 factors.
5528 * This allows us to precompute the above in said factors, thereby allowing the
5529 * reduction of an arbitrary n in O(log_2 n) steps. (See also
5530 * fixed_power_int())
5531 *
5532 * The calculation is approximated on a 128 point scale.
5533 */
5534#define DEGRADE_SHIFT 7
5535
5536static const u8 degrade_zero_ticks[CPU_LOAD_IDX_MAX] = {0, 8, 32, 64, 128};
5537static const u8 degrade_factor[CPU_LOAD_IDX_MAX][DEGRADE_SHIFT + 1] = {
5538 { 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 },
5539 { 64, 32, 8, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 },
5540 { 96, 72, 40, 12, 1, 0, 0, 0 },
5541 { 112, 98, 75, 43, 15, 1, 0, 0 },
5542 { 120, 112, 98, 76, 45, 16, 2, 0 }
5543};
5544
5545/*
5546 * Update cpu_load for any missed ticks, due to tickless idle. The backlog
5547 * would be when CPU is idle and so we just decay the old load without
5548 * adding any new load.
5549 */
5550static unsigned long
5551decay_load_missed(unsigned long load, unsigned long missed_updates, int idx)
5552{
5553 int j = 0;
5554
5555 if (!missed_updates)
5556 return load;
5557
5558 if (missed_updates >= degrade_zero_ticks[idx])
5559 return 0;
5560
5561 if (idx == 1)
5562 return load >> missed_updates;
5563
5564 while (missed_updates) {
5565 if (missed_updates % 2)
5566 load = (load * degrade_factor[idx][j]) >> DEGRADE_SHIFT;
5567
5568 missed_updates >>= 1;
5569 j++;
5570 }
5571 return load;
5572}
5573
5574static struct {
5575 cpumask_var_t idle_cpus_mask;
5576 atomic_t nr_cpus;
5577 int has_blocked; /* Idle CPUS has blocked load */
5578 unsigned long next_balance; /* in jiffy units */
5579 unsigned long next_blocked; /* Next update of blocked load in jiffies */
5580} nohz ____cacheline_aligned;
5581
5582#endif /* CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON */
5583
5584/**
5585 * __cpu_load_update - update the rq->cpu_load[] statistics
5586 * @this_rq: The rq to update statistics for
5587 * @this_load: The current load
5588 * @pending_updates: The number of missed updates
5589 *
5590 * Update rq->cpu_load[] statistics. This function is usually called every
5591 * scheduler tick (TICK_NSEC).
5592 *
5593 * This function computes a decaying average:
5594 *
5595 * load[i]' = (1 - 1/2^i) * load[i] + (1/2^i) * load
5596 *
5597 * Because of NOHZ it might not get called on every tick which gives need for
5598 * the @pending_updates argument.
5599 *
5600 * load[i]_n = (1 - 1/2^i) * load[i]_n-1 + (1/2^i) * load_n-1
5601 * = A * load[i]_n-1 + B ; A := (1 - 1/2^i), B := (1/2^i) * load
5602 * = A * (A * load[i]_n-2 + B) + B
5603 * = A * (A * (A * load[i]_n-3 + B) + B) + B
5604 * = A^3 * load[i]_n-3 + (A^2 + A + 1) * B
5605 * = A^n * load[i]_0 + (A^(n-1) + A^(n-2) + ... + 1) * B
5606 * = A^n * load[i]_0 + ((1 - A^n) / (1 - A)) * B
5607 * = (1 - 1/2^i)^n * (load[i]_0 - load) + load
5608 *
5609 * In the above we've assumed load_n := load, which is true for NOHZ_FULL as
5610 * any change in load would have resulted in the tick being turned back on.
5611 *
5612 * For regular NOHZ, this reduces to:
5613 *
5614 * load[i]_n = (1 - 1/2^i)^n * load[i]_0
5615 *
5616 * see decay_load_misses(). For NOHZ_FULL we get to subtract and add the extra
5617 * term.
5618 */
5619static void cpu_load_update(struct rq *this_rq, unsigned long this_load,
5620 unsigned long pending_updates)
5621{
5622 unsigned long __maybe_unused tickless_load = this_rq->cpu_load[0];
5623 int i, scale;
5624
5625 this_rq->nr_load_updates++;
5626
5627 /* Update our load: */
5628 this_rq->cpu_load[0] = this_load; /* Fasttrack for idx 0 */
5629 for (i = 1, scale = 2; i < CPU_LOAD_IDX_MAX; i++, scale += scale) {
5630 unsigned long old_load, new_load;
5631
5632 /* scale is effectively 1 << i now, and >> i divides by scale */
5633
5634 old_load = this_rq->cpu_load[i];
5635#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
5636 old_load = decay_load_missed(old_load, pending_updates - 1, i);
5637 if (tickless_load) {
5638 old_load -= decay_load_missed(tickless_load, pending_updates - 1, i);
5639 /*
5640 * old_load can never be a negative value because a
5641 * decayed tickless_load cannot be greater than the
5642 * original tickless_load.
5643 */
5644 old_load += tickless_load;
5645 }
5646#endif
5647 new_load = this_load;
5648 /*
5649 * Round up the averaging division if load is increasing. This
5650 * prevents us from getting stuck on 9 if the load is 10, for
5651 * example.
5652 */
5653 if (new_load > old_load)
5654 new_load += scale - 1;
5655
5656 this_rq->cpu_load[i] = (old_load * (scale - 1) + new_load) >> i;
5657 }
5658
5659 sched_avg_update(this_rq);
5660}
5661
5662/* Used instead of source_load when we know the type == 0 */
5663static unsigned long weighted_cpuload(struct rq *rq)
5664{
5665 return cfs_rq_runnable_load_avg(&rq->cfs);
5666}
5667
5668#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
5669/*
5670 * There is no sane way to deal with nohz on smp when using jiffies because the
5671 * CPU doing the jiffies update might drift wrt the CPU doing the jiffy reading
5672 * causing off-by-one errors in observed deltas; {0,2} instead of {1,1}.
5673 *
5674 * Therefore we need to avoid the delta approach from the regular tick when
5675 * possible since that would seriously skew the load calculation. This is why we
5676 * use cpu_load_update_periodic() for CPUs out of nohz. However we'll rely on
5677 * jiffies deltas for updates happening while in nohz mode (idle ticks, idle
5678 * loop exit, nohz_idle_balance, nohz full exit...)
5679 *
5680 * This means we might still be one tick off for nohz periods.
5681 */
5682
5683static void cpu_load_update_nohz(struct rq *this_rq,
5684 unsigned long curr_jiffies,
5685 unsigned long load)
5686{
5687 unsigned long pending_updates;
5688
5689 pending_updates = curr_jiffies - this_rq->last_load_update_tick;
5690 if (pending_updates) {
5691 this_rq->last_load_update_tick = curr_jiffies;
5692 /*
5693 * In the regular NOHZ case, we were idle, this means load 0.
5694 * In the NOHZ_FULL case, we were non-idle, we should consider
5695 * its weighted load.
5696 */
5697 cpu_load_update(this_rq, load, pending_updates);
5698 }
5699}
5700
5701/*
5702 * Called from nohz_idle_balance() to update the load ratings before doing the
5703 * idle balance.
5704 */
5705static void cpu_load_update_idle(struct rq *this_rq)
5706{
5707 /*
5708 * bail if there's load or we're actually up-to-date.
5709 */
5710 if (weighted_cpuload(this_rq))
5711 return;
5712
5713 cpu_load_update_nohz(this_rq, READ_ONCE(jiffies), 0);
5714}
5715
5716/*
5717 * Record CPU load on nohz entry so we know the tickless load to account
5718 * on nohz exit. cpu_load[0] happens then to be updated more frequently
5719 * than other cpu_load[idx] but it should be fine as cpu_load readers
5720 * shouldn't rely into synchronized cpu_load[*] updates.
5721 */
5722void cpu_load_update_nohz_start(void)
5723{
5724 struct rq *this_rq = this_rq();
5725
5726 /*
5727 * This is all lockless but should be fine. If weighted_cpuload changes
5728 * concurrently we'll exit nohz. And cpu_load write can race with
5729 * cpu_load_update_idle() but both updater would be writing the same.
5730 */
5731 this_rq->cpu_load[0] = weighted_cpuload(this_rq);
5732}
5733
5734/*
5735 * Account the tickless load in the end of a nohz frame.
5736 */
5737void cpu_load_update_nohz_stop(void)
5738{
5739 unsigned long curr_jiffies = READ_ONCE(jiffies);
5740 struct rq *this_rq = this_rq();
5741 unsigned long load;
5742 struct rq_flags rf;
5743
5744 if (curr_jiffies == this_rq->last_load_update_tick)
5745 return;
5746
5747 load = weighted_cpuload(this_rq);
5748 rq_lock(this_rq, &rf);
5749 update_rq_clock(this_rq);
5750 cpu_load_update_nohz(this_rq, curr_jiffies, load);
5751 rq_unlock(this_rq, &rf);
5752}
5753#else /* !CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON */
5754static inline void cpu_load_update_nohz(struct rq *this_rq,
5755 unsigned long curr_jiffies,
5756 unsigned long load) { }
5757#endif /* CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON */
5758
5759static void cpu_load_update_periodic(struct rq *this_rq, unsigned long load)
5760{
5761#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
5762 /* See the mess around cpu_load_update_nohz(). */
5763 this_rq->last_load_update_tick = READ_ONCE(jiffies);
5764#endif
5765 cpu_load_update(this_rq, load, 1);
5766}
5767
5768/*
5769 * Called from scheduler_tick()
5770 */
5771void cpu_load_update_active(struct rq *this_rq)
5772{
5773 unsigned long load = weighted_cpuload(this_rq);
5774
5775 if (tick_nohz_tick_stopped())
5776 cpu_load_update_nohz(this_rq, READ_ONCE(jiffies), load);
5777 else
5778 cpu_load_update_periodic(this_rq, load);
5779}
5780
5781/*
5782 * Return a low guess at the load of a migration-source CPU weighted
5783 * according to the scheduling class and "nice" value.
5784 *
5785 * We want to under-estimate the load of migration sources, to
5786 * balance conservatively.
5787 */
5788static unsigned long source_load(int cpu, int type)
5789{
5790 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
5791 unsigned long total = weighted_cpuload(rq);
5792
5793 if (type == 0 || !sched_feat(LB_BIAS))
5794 return total;
5795
5796 return min(rq->cpu_load[type-1], total);
5797}
5798
5799/*
5800 * Return a high guess at the load of a migration-target CPU weighted
5801 * according to the scheduling class and "nice" value.
5802 */
5803static unsigned long target_load(int cpu, int type)
5804{
5805 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
5806 unsigned long total = weighted_cpuload(rq);
5807
5808 if (type == 0 || !sched_feat(LB_BIAS))
5809 return total;
5810
5811 return max(rq->cpu_load[type-1], total);
5812}
5813
5814static unsigned long capacity_of(int cpu)
5815{
5816 return cpu_rq(cpu)->cpu_capacity;
5817}
5818
5819static unsigned long capacity_orig_of(int cpu)
5820{
5821 return cpu_rq(cpu)->cpu_capacity_orig;
5822}
5823
5824static unsigned long cpu_avg_load_per_task(int cpu)
5825{
5826 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
5827 unsigned long nr_running = READ_ONCE(rq->cfs.h_nr_running);
5828 unsigned long load_avg = weighted_cpuload(rq);
5829
5830 if (nr_running)
5831 return load_avg / nr_running;
5832
5833 return 0;
5834}
5835
5836static void record_wakee(struct task_struct *p)
5837{
5838 /*
5839 * Only decay a single time; tasks that have less then 1 wakeup per
5840 * jiffy will not have built up many flips.
5841 */
5842 if (time_after(jiffies, current->wakee_flip_decay_ts + HZ)) {
5843 current->wakee_flips >>= 1;
5844 current->wakee_flip_decay_ts = jiffies;
5845 }
5846
5847 if (current->last_wakee != p) {
5848 current->last_wakee = p;
5849 current->wakee_flips++;
5850 }
5851}
5852
5853/*
5854 * Detect M:N waker/wakee relationships via a switching-frequency heuristic.
5855 *
5856 * A waker of many should wake a different task than the one last awakened
5857 * at a frequency roughly N times higher than one of its wakees.
5858 *
5859 * In order to determine whether we should let the load spread vs consolidating
5860 * to shared cache, we look for a minimum 'flip' frequency of llc_size in one
5861 * partner, and a factor of lls_size higher frequency in the other.
5862 *
5863 * With both conditions met, we can be relatively sure that the relationship is
5864 * non-monogamous, with partner count exceeding socket size.
5865 *
5866 * Waker/wakee being client/server, worker/dispatcher, interrupt source or
5867 * whatever is irrelevant, spread criteria is apparent partner count exceeds
5868 * socket size.
5869 */
5870static int wake_wide(struct task_struct *p)
5871{
5872 unsigned int master = current->wakee_flips;
5873 unsigned int slave = p->wakee_flips;
5874 int factor = this_cpu_read(sd_llc_size);
5875
5876 if (master < slave)
5877 swap(master, slave);
5878 if (slave < factor || master < slave * factor)
5879 return 0;
5880 return 1;
5881}
5882
5883/*
5884 * The purpose of wake_affine() is to quickly determine on which CPU we can run
5885 * soonest. For the purpose of speed we only consider the waking and previous
5886 * CPU.
5887 *
5888 * wake_affine_idle() - only considers 'now', it check if the waking CPU is
5889 * cache-affine and is (or will be) idle.
5890 *
5891 * wake_affine_weight() - considers the weight to reflect the average
5892 * scheduling latency of the CPUs. This seems to work
5893 * for the overloaded case.
5894 */
5895static int
5896wake_affine_idle(int this_cpu, int prev_cpu, int sync)
5897{
5898 /*
5899 * If this_cpu is idle, it implies the wakeup is from interrupt
5900 * context. Only allow the move if cache is shared. Otherwise an
5901 * interrupt intensive workload could force all tasks onto one
5902 * node depending on the IO topology or IRQ affinity settings.
5903 *
5904 * If the prev_cpu is idle and cache affine then avoid a migration.
5905 * There is no guarantee that the cache hot data from an interrupt
5906 * is more important than cache hot data on the prev_cpu and from
5907 * a cpufreq perspective, it's better to have higher utilisation
5908 * on one CPU.
5909 */
5910 if (available_idle_cpu(this_cpu) && cpus_share_cache(this_cpu, prev_cpu))
5911 return available_idle_cpu(prev_cpu) ? prev_cpu : this_cpu;
5912
5913 if (sync && cpu_rq(this_cpu)->nr_running == 1)
5914 return this_cpu;
5915
5916 return nr_cpumask_bits;
5917}
5918
5919static int
5920wake_affine_weight(struct sched_domain *sd, struct task_struct *p,
5921 int this_cpu, int prev_cpu, int sync)
5922{
5923 s64 this_eff_load, prev_eff_load;
5924 unsigned long task_load;
5925
5926 this_eff_load = target_load(this_cpu, sd->wake_idx);
5927
5928 if (sync) {
5929 unsigned long current_load = task_h_load(current);
5930
5931 if (current_load > this_eff_load)
5932 return this_cpu;
5933
5934 this_eff_load -= current_load;
5935 }
5936
5937 task_load = task_h_load(p);
5938
5939 this_eff_load += task_load;
5940 if (sched_feat(WA_BIAS))
5941 this_eff_load *= 100;
5942 this_eff_load *= capacity_of(prev_cpu);
5943
5944 prev_eff_load = source_load(prev_cpu, sd->wake_idx);
5945 prev_eff_load -= task_load;
5946 if (sched_feat(WA_BIAS))
5947 prev_eff_load *= 100 + (sd->imbalance_pct - 100) / 2;
5948 prev_eff_load *= capacity_of(this_cpu);
5949
5950 /*
5951 * If sync, adjust the weight of prev_eff_load such that if
5952 * prev_eff == this_eff that select_idle_sibling() will consider
5953 * stacking the wakee on top of the waker if no other CPU is
5954 * idle.
5955 */
5956 if (sync)
5957 prev_eff_load += 1;
5958
5959 return this_eff_load < prev_eff_load ? this_cpu : nr_cpumask_bits;
5960}
5961
5962static int wake_affine(struct sched_domain *sd, struct task_struct *p,
5963 int this_cpu, int prev_cpu, int sync)
5964{
5965 int target = nr_cpumask_bits;
5966
5967 if (sched_feat(WA_IDLE))
5968 target = wake_affine_idle(this_cpu, prev_cpu, sync);
5969
5970 if (sched_feat(WA_WEIGHT) && target == nr_cpumask_bits)
5971 target = wake_affine_weight(sd, p, this_cpu, prev_cpu, sync);
5972
5973 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_affine_attempts);
5974 if (target == nr_cpumask_bits)
5975 return prev_cpu;
5976
5977 schedstat_inc(sd->ttwu_move_affine);
5978 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_wakeups_affine);
5979 return target;
5980}
5981
5982static unsigned long cpu_util_wake(int cpu, struct task_struct *p);
5983
5984static unsigned long capacity_spare_wake(int cpu, struct task_struct *p)
5985{
5986 return max_t(long, capacity_of(cpu) - cpu_util_wake(cpu, p), 0);
5987}
5988
5989/*
5990 * find_idlest_group finds and returns the least busy CPU group within the
5991 * domain.
5992 *
5993 * Assumes p is allowed on at least one CPU in sd.
5994 */
5995static struct sched_group *
5996find_idlest_group(struct sched_domain *sd, struct task_struct *p,
5997 int this_cpu, int sd_flag)
5998{
5999 struct sched_group *idlest = NULL, *group = sd->groups;
6000 struct sched_group *most_spare_sg = NULL;
6001 unsigned long min_runnable_load = ULONG_MAX;
6002 unsigned long this_runnable_load = ULONG_MAX;
6003 unsigned long min_avg_load = ULONG_MAX, this_avg_load = ULONG_MAX;
6004 unsigned long most_spare = 0, this_spare = 0;
6005 int load_idx = sd->forkexec_idx;
6006 int imbalance_scale = 100 + (sd->imbalance_pct-100)/2;
6007 unsigned long imbalance = scale_load_down(NICE_0_LOAD) *
6008 (sd->imbalance_pct-100) / 100;
6009
6010 if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_WAKE)
6011 load_idx = sd->wake_idx;
6012
6013 do {
6014 unsigned long load, avg_load, runnable_load;
6015 unsigned long spare_cap, max_spare_cap;
6016 int local_group;
6017 int i;
6018
6019 /* Skip over this group if it has no CPUs allowed */
6020 if (!cpumask_intersects(sched_group_span(group),
6021 &p->cpus_allowed))
6022 continue;
6023
6024 local_group = cpumask_test_cpu(this_cpu,
6025 sched_group_span(group));
6026
6027 /*
6028 * Tally up the load of all CPUs in the group and find
6029 * the group containing the CPU with most spare capacity.
6030 */
6031 avg_load = 0;
6032 runnable_load = 0;
6033 max_spare_cap = 0;
6034
6035 for_each_cpu(i, sched_group_span(group)) {
6036 /* Bias balancing toward CPUs of our domain */
6037 if (local_group)
6038 load = source_load(i, load_idx);
6039 else
6040 load = target_load(i, load_idx);
6041
6042 runnable_load += load;
6043
6044 avg_load += cfs_rq_load_avg(&cpu_rq(i)->cfs);
6045
6046 spare_cap = capacity_spare_wake(i, p);
6047
6048 if (spare_cap > max_spare_cap)
6049 max_spare_cap = spare_cap;
6050 }
6051
6052 /* Adjust by relative CPU capacity of the group */
6053 avg_load = (avg_load * SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE) /
6054 group->sgc->capacity;
6055 runnable_load = (runnable_load * SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE) /
6056 group->sgc->capacity;
6057
6058 if (local_group) {
6059 this_runnable_load = runnable_load;
6060 this_avg_load = avg_load;
6061 this_spare = max_spare_cap;
6062 } else {
6063 if (min_runnable_load > (runnable_load + imbalance)) {
6064 /*
6065 * The runnable load is significantly smaller
6066 * so we can pick this new CPU:
6067 */
6068 min_runnable_load = runnable_load;
6069 min_avg_load = avg_load;
6070 idlest = group;
6071 } else if ((runnable_load < (min_runnable_load + imbalance)) &&
6072 (100*min_avg_load > imbalance_scale*avg_load)) {
6073 /*
6074 * The runnable loads are close so take the
6075 * blocked load into account through avg_load:
6076 */
6077 min_avg_load = avg_load;
6078 idlest = group;
6079 }
6080
6081 if (most_spare < max_spare_cap) {
6082 most_spare = max_spare_cap;
6083 most_spare_sg = group;
6084 }
6085 }
6086 } while (group = group->next, group != sd->groups);
6087
6088 /*
6089 * The cross-over point between using spare capacity or least load
6090 * is too conservative for high utilization tasks on partially
6091 * utilized systems if we require spare_capacity > task_util(p),
6092 * so we allow for some task stuffing by using
6093 * spare_capacity > task_util(p)/2.
6094 *
6095 * Spare capacity can't be used for fork because the utilization has
6096 * not been set yet, we must first select a rq to compute the initial
6097 * utilization.
6098 */
6099 if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_FORK)
6100 goto skip_spare;
6101
6102 if (this_spare > task_util(p) / 2 &&
6103 imbalance_scale*this_spare > 100*most_spare)
6104 return NULL;
6105
6106 if (most_spare > task_util(p) / 2)
6107 return most_spare_sg;
6108
6109skip_spare:
6110 if (!idlest)
6111 return NULL;
6112
6113 /*
6114 * When comparing groups across NUMA domains, it's possible for the
6115 * local domain to be very lightly loaded relative to the remote
6116 * domains but "imbalance" skews the comparison making remote CPUs
6117 * look much more favourable. When considering cross-domain, add
6118 * imbalance to the runnable load on the remote node and consider
6119 * staying local.
6120 */
6121 if ((sd->flags & SD_NUMA) &&
6122 min_runnable_load + imbalance >= this_runnable_load)
6123 return NULL;
6124
6125 if (min_runnable_load > (this_runnable_load + imbalance))
6126 return NULL;
6127
6128 if ((this_runnable_load < (min_runnable_load + imbalance)) &&
6129 (100*this_avg_load < imbalance_scale*min_avg_load))
6130 return NULL;
6131
6132 return idlest;
6133}
6134
6135/*
6136 * find_idlest_group_cpu - find the idlest CPU among the CPUs in the group.
6137 */
6138static int
6139find_idlest_group_cpu(struct sched_group *group, struct task_struct *p, int this_cpu)
6140{
6141 unsigned long load, min_load = ULONG_MAX;
6142 unsigned int min_exit_latency = UINT_MAX;
6143 u64 latest_idle_timestamp = 0;
6144 int least_loaded_cpu = this_cpu;
6145 int shallowest_idle_cpu = -1;
6146 int i;
6147
6148 /* Check if we have any choice: */
6149 if (group->group_weight == 1)
6150 return cpumask_first(sched_group_span(group));
6151
6152 /* Traverse only the allowed CPUs */
6153 for_each_cpu_and(i, sched_group_span(group), &p->cpus_allowed) {
6154 if (available_idle_cpu(i)) {
6155 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(i);
6156 struct cpuidle_state *idle = idle_get_state(rq);
6157 if (idle && idle->exit_latency < min_exit_latency) {
6158 /*
6159 * We give priority to a CPU whose idle state
6160 * has the smallest exit latency irrespective
6161 * of any idle timestamp.
6162 */
6163 min_exit_latency = idle->exit_latency;
6164 latest_idle_timestamp = rq->idle_stamp;
6165 shallowest_idle_cpu = i;
6166 } else if ((!idle || idle->exit_latency == min_exit_latency) &&
6167 rq->idle_stamp > latest_idle_timestamp) {
6168 /*
6169 * If equal or no active idle state, then
6170 * the most recently idled CPU might have
6171 * a warmer cache.
6172 */
6173 latest_idle_timestamp = rq->idle_stamp;
6174 shallowest_idle_cpu = i;
6175 }
6176 } else if (shallowest_idle_cpu == -1) {
6177 load = weighted_cpuload(cpu_rq(i));
6178 if (load < min_load) {
6179 min_load = load;
6180 least_loaded_cpu = i;
6181 }
6182 }
6183 }
6184
6185 return shallowest_idle_cpu != -1 ? shallowest_idle_cpu : least_loaded_cpu;
6186}
6187
6188static inline int find_idlest_cpu(struct sched_domain *sd, struct task_struct *p,
6189 int cpu, int prev_cpu, int sd_flag)
6190{
6191 int new_cpu = cpu;
6192
6193 if (!cpumask_intersects(sched_domain_span(sd), &p->cpus_allowed))
6194 return prev_cpu;
6195
6196 /*
6197 * We need task's util for capacity_spare_wake, sync it up to prev_cpu's
6198 * last_update_time.
6199 */
6200 if (!(sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_FORK))
6201 sync_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6202
6203 while (sd) {
6204 struct sched_group *group;
6205 struct sched_domain *tmp;
6206 int weight;
6207
6208 if (!(sd->flags & sd_flag)) {
6209 sd = sd->child;
6210 continue;
6211 }
6212
6213 group = find_idlest_group(sd, p, cpu, sd_flag);
6214 if (!group) {
6215 sd = sd->child;
6216 continue;
6217 }
6218
6219 new_cpu = find_idlest_group_cpu(group, p, cpu);
6220 if (new_cpu == cpu) {
6221 /* Now try balancing at a lower domain level of 'cpu': */
6222 sd = sd->child;
6223 continue;
6224 }
6225
6226 /* Now try balancing at a lower domain level of 'new_cpu': */
6227 cpu = new_cpu;
6228 weight = sd->span_weight;
6229 sd = NULL;
6230 for_each_domain(cpu, tmp) {
6231 if (weight <= tmp->span_weight)
6232 break;
6233 if (tmp->flags & sd_flag)
6234 sd = tmp;
6235 }
6236 }
6237
6238 return new_cpu;
6239}
6240
6241#ifdef CONFIG_SCHED_SMT
6242DEFINE_STATIC_KEY_FALSE(sched_smt_present);
6243
6244static inline void set_idle_cores(int cpu, int val)
6245{
6246 struct sched_domain_shared *sds;
6247
6248 sds = rcu_dereference(per_cpu(sd_llc_shared, cpu));
6249 if (sds)
6250 WRITE_ONCE(sds->has_idle_cores, val);
6251}
6252
6253static inline bool test_idle_cores(int cpu, bool def)
6254{
6255 struct sched_domain_shared *sds;
6256
6257 sds = rcu_dereference(per_cpu(sd_llc_shared, cpu));
6258 if (sds)
6259 return READ_ONCE(sds->has_idle_cores);
6260
6261 return def;
6262}
6263
6264/*
6265 * Scans the local SMT mask to see if the entire core is idle, and records this
6266 * information in sd_llc_shared->has_idle_cores.
6267 *
6268 * Since SMT siblings share all cache levels, inspecting this limited remote
6269 * state should be fairly cheap.
6270 */
6271void __update_idle_core(struct rq *rq)
6272{
6273 int core = cpu_of(rq);
6274 int cpu;
6275
6276 rcu_read_lock();
6277 if (test_idle_cores(core, true))
6278 goto unlock;
6279
6280 for_each_cpu(cpu, cpu_smt_mask(core)) {
6281 if (cpu == core)
6282 continue;
6283
6284 if (!available_idle_cpu(cpu))
6285 goto unlock;
6286 }
6287
6288 set_idle_cores(core, 1);
6289unlock:
6290 rcu_read_unlock();
6291}
6292
6293/*
6294 * Scan the entire LLC domain for idle cores; this dynamically switches off if
6295 * there are no idle cores left in the system; tracked through
6296 * sd_llc->shared->has_idle_cores and enabled through update_idle_core() above.
6297 */
6298static int select_idle_core(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
6299{
6300 struct cpumask *cpus = this_cpu_cpumask_var_ptr(select_idle_mask);
6301 int core, cpu;
6302
6303 if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_smt_present))
6304 return -1;
6305
6306 if (!test_idle_cores(target, false))
6307 return -1;
6308
6309 cpumask_and(cpus, sched_domain_span(sd), &p->cpus_allowed);
6310
6311 for_each_cpu_wrap(core, cpus, target) {
6312 bool idle = true;
6313
6314 for_each_cpu(cpu, cpu_smt_mask(core)) {
6315 cpumask_clear_cpu(cpu, cpus);
6316 if (!available_idle_cpu(cpu))
6317 idle = false;
6318 }
6319
6320 if (idle)
6321 return core;
6322 }
6323
6324 /*
6325 * Failed to find an idle core; stop looking for one.
6326 */
6327 set_idle_cores(target, 0);
6328
6329 return -1;
6330}
6331
6332/*
6333 * Scan the local SMT mask for idle CPUs.
6334 */
6335static int select_idle_smt(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
6336{
6337 int cpu;
6338
6339 if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_smt_present))
6340 return -1;
6341
6342 for_each_cpu(cpu, cpu_smt_mask(target)) {
6343 if (!cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, &p->cpus_allowed))
6344 continue;
6345 if (available_idle_cpu(cpu))
6346 return cpu;
6347 }
6348
6349 return -1;
6350}
6351
6352#else /* CONFIG_SCHED_SMT */
6353
6354static inline int select_idle_core(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
6355{
6356 return -1;
6357}
6358
6359static inline int select_idle_smt(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
6360{
6361 return -1;
6362}
6363
6364#endif /* CONFIG_SCHED_SMT */
6365
6366/*
6367 * Scan the LLC domain for idle CPUs; this is dynamically regulated by
6368 * comparing the average scan cost (tracked in sd->avg_scan_cost) against the
6369 * average idle time for this rq (as found in rq->avg_idle).
6370 */
6371static int select_idle_cpu(struct task_struct *p, struct sched_domain *sd, int target)
6372{
6373 struct sched_domain *this_sd;
6374 u64 avg_cost, avg_idle;
6375 u64 time, cost;
6376 s64 delta;
6377 int cpu, nr = INT_MAX;
6378
6379 this_sd = rcu_dereference(*this_cpu_ptr(&sd_llc));
6380 if (!this_sd)
6381 return -1;
6382
6383 /*
6384 * Due to large variance we need a large fuzz factor; hackbench in
6385 * particularly is sensitive here.
6386 */
6387 avg_idle = this_rq()->avg_idle / 512;
6388 avg_cost = this_sd->avg_scan_cost + 1;
6389
6390 if (sched_feat(SIS_AVG_CPU) && avg_idle < avg_cost)
6391 return -1;
6392
6393 if (sched_feat(SIS_PROP)) {
6394 u64 span_avg = sd->span_weight * avg_idle;
6395 if (span_avg > 4*avg_cost)
6396 nr = div_u64(span_avg, avg_cost);
6397 else
6398 nr = 4;
6399 }
6400
6401 time = local_clock();
6402
6403 for_each_cpu_wrap(cpu, sched_domain_span(sd), target) {
6404 if (!--nr)
6405 return -1;
6406 if (!cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, &p->cpus_allowed))
6407 continue;
6408 if (available_idle_cpu(cpu))
6409 break;
6410 }
6411
6412 time = local_clock() - time;
6413 cost = this_sd->avg_scan_cost;
6414 delta = (s64)(time - cost) / 8;
6415 this_sd->avg_scan_cost += delta;
6416
6417 return cpu;
6418}
6419
6420/*
6421 * Try and locate an idle core/thread in the LLC cache domain.
6422 */
6423static int select_idle_sibling(struct task_struct *p, int prev, int target)
6424{
6425 struct sched_domain *sd;
6426 int i, recent_used_cpu;
6427
6428 if (available_idle_cpu(target))
6429 return target;
6430
6431 /*
6432 * If the previous CPU is cache affine and idle, don't be stupid:
6433 */
6434 if (prev != target && cpus_share_cache(prev, target) && available_idle_cpu(prev))
6435 return prev;
6436
6437 /* Check a recently used CPU as a potential idle candidate: */
6438 recent_used_cpu = p->recent_used_cpu;
6439 if (recent_used_cpu != prev &&
6440 recent_used_cpu != target &&
6441 cpus_share_cache(recent_used_cpu, target) &&
6442 available_idle_cpu(recent_used_cpu) &&
6443 cpumask_test_cpu(p->recent_used_cpu, &p->cpus_allowed)) {
6444 /*
6445 * Replace recent_used_cpu with prev as it is a potential
6446 * candidate for the next wake:
6447 */
6448 p->recent_used_cpu = prev;
6449 return recent_used_cpu;
6450 }
6451
6452 sd = rcu_dereference(per_cpu(sd_llc, target));
6453 if (!sd)
6454 return target;
6455
6456 i = select_idle_core(p, sd, target);
6457 if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6458 return i;
6459
6460 i = select_idle_cpu(p, sd, target);
6461 if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6462 return i;
6463
6464 i = select_idle_smt(p, sd, target);
6465 if ((unsigned)i < nr_cpumask_bits)
6466 return i;
6467
6468 return target;
6469}
6470
6471/**
6472 * Amount of capacity of a CPU that is (estimated to be) used by CFS tasks
6473 * @cpu: the CPU to get the utilization of
6474 *
6475 * The unit of the return value must be the one of capacity so we can compare
6476 * the utilization with the capacity of the CPU that is available for CFS task
6477 * (ie cpu_capacity).
6478 *
6479 * cfs_rq.avg.util_avg is the sum of running time of runnable tasks plus the
6480 * recent utilization of currently non-runnable tasks on a CPU. It represents
6481 * the amount of utilization of a CPU in the range [0..capacity_orig] where
6482 * capacity_orig is the cpu_capacity available at the highest frequency
6483 * (arch_scale_freq_capacity()).
6484 * The utilization of a CPU converges towards a sum equal to or less than the
6485 * current capacity (capacity_curr <= capacity_orig) of the CPU because it is
6486 * the running time on this CPU scaled by capacity_curr.
6487 *
6488 * The estimated utilization of a CPU is defined to be the maximum between its
6489 * cfs_rq.avg.util_avg and the sum of the estimated utilization of the tasks
6490 * currently RUNNABLE on that CPU.
6491 * This allows to properly represent the expected utilization of a CPU which
6492 * has just got a big task running since a long sleep period. At the same time
6493 * however it preserves the benefits of the "blocked utilization" in
6494 * describing the potential for other tasks waking up on the same CPU.
6495 *
6496 * Nevertheless, cfs_rq.avg.util_avg can be higher than capacity_curr or even
6497 * higher than capacity_orig because of unfortunate rounding in
6498 * cfs.avg.util_avg or just after migrating tasks and new task wakeups until
6499 * the average stabilizes with the new running time. We need to check that the
6500 * utilization stays within the range of [0..capacity_orig] and cap it if
6501 * necessary. Without utilization capping, a group could be seen as overloaded
6502 * (CPU0 utilization at 121% + CPU1 utilization at 80%) whereas CPU1 has 20% of
6503 * available capacity. We allow utilization to overshoot capacity_curr (but not
6504 * capacity_orig) as it useful for predicting the capacity required after task
6505 * migrations (scheduler-driven DVFS).
6506 *
6507 * Return: the (estimated) utilization for the specified CPU
6508 */
6509static inline unsigned long cpu_util(int cpu)
6510{
6511 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
6512 unsigned int util;
6513
6514 cfs_rq = &cpu_rq(cpu)->cfs;
6515 util = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_avg);
6516
6517 if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
6518 util = max(util, READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued));
6519
6520 return min_t(unsigned long, util, capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6521}
6522
6523/*
6524 * cpu_util_wake: Compute CPU utilization with any contributions from
6525 * the waking task p removed.
6526 */
6527static unsigned long cpu_util_wake(int cpu, struct task_struct *p)
6528{
6529 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
6530 unsigned int util;
6531
6532 /* Task has no contribution or is new */
6533 if (cpu != task_cpu(p) || !READ_ONCE(p->se.avg.last_update_time))
6534 return cpu_util(cpu);
6535
6536 cfs_rq = &cpu_rq(cpu)->cfs;
6537 util = READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_avg);
6538
6539 /* Discount task's blocked util from CPU's util */
6540 util -= min_t(unsigned int, util, task_util(p));
6541
6542 /*
6543 * Covered cases:
6544 *
6545 * a) if *p is the only task sleeping on this CPU, then:
6546 * cpu_util (== task_util) > util_est (== 0)
6547 * and thus we return:
6548 * cpu_util_wake = (cpu_util - task_util) = 0
6549 *
6550 * b) if other tasks are SLEEPING on this CPU, which is now exiting
6551 * IDLE, then:
6552 * cpu_util >= task_util
6553 * cpu_util > util_est (== 0)
6554 * and thus we discount *p's blocked utilization to return:
6555 * cpu_util_wake = (cpu_util - task_util) >= 0
6556 *
6557 * c) if other tasks are RUNNABLE on that CPU and
6558 * util_est > cpu_util
6559 * then we use util_est since it returns a more restrictive
6560 * estimation of the spare capacity on that CPU, by just
6561 * considering the expected utilization of tasks already
6562 * runnable on that CPU.
6563 *
6564 * Cases a) and b) are covered by the above code, while case c) is
6565 * covered by the following code when estimated utilization is
6566 * enabled.
6567 */
6568 if (sched_feat(UTIL_EST))
6569 util = max(util, READ_ONCE(cfs_rq->avg.util_est.enqueued));
6570
6571 /*
6572 * Utilization (estimated) can exceed the CPU capacity, thus let's
6573 * clamp to the maximum CPU capacity to ensure consistency with
6574 * the cpu_util call.
6575 */
6576 return min_t(unsigned long, util, capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6577}
6578
6579/*
6580 * Disable WAKE_AFFINE in the case where task @p doesn't fit in the
6581 * capacity of either the waking CPU @cpu or the previous CPU @prev_cpu.
6582 *
6583 * In that case WAKE_AFFINE doesn't make sense and we'll let
6584 * BALANCE_WAKE sort things out.
6585 */
6586static int wake_cap(struct task_struct *p, int cpu, int prev_cpu)
6587{
6588 long min_cap, max_cap;
6589
6590 min_cap = min(capacity_orig_of(prev_cpu), capacity_orig_of(cpu));
6591 max_cap = cpu_rq(cpu)->rd->max_cpu_capacity;
6592
6593 /* Minimum capacity is close to max, no need to abort wake_affine */
6594 if (max_cap - min_cap < max_cap >> 3)
6595 return 0;
6596
6597 /* Bring task utilization in sync with prev_cpu */
6598 sync_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6599
6600 return min_cap * 1024 < task_util(p) * capacity_margin;
6601}
6602
6603/*
6604 * select_task_rq_fair: Select target runqueue for the waking task in domains
6605 * that have the 'sd_flag' flag set. In practice, this is SD_BALANCE_WAKE,
6606 * SD_BALANCE_FORK, or SD_BALANCE_EXEC.
6607 *
6608 * Balances load by selecting the idlest CPU in the idlest group, or under
6609 * certain conditions an idle sibling CPU if the domain has SD_WAKE_AFFINE set.
6610 *
6611 * Returns the target CPU number.
6612 *
6613 * preempt must be disabled.
6614 */
6615static int
6616select_task_rq_fair(struct task_struct *p, int prev_cpu, int sd_flag, int wake_flags)
6617{
6618 struct sched_domain *tmp, *sd = NULL;
6619 int cpu = smp_processor_id();
6620 int new_cpu = prev_cpu;
6621 int want_affine = 0;
6622 int sync = (wake_flags & WF_SYNC) && !(current->flags & PF_EXITING);
6623
6624 if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_WAKE) {
6625 record_wakee(p);
6626 want_affine = !wake_wide(p) && !wake_cap(p, cpu, prev_cpu)
6627 && cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, &p->cpus_allowed);
6628 }
6629
6630 rcu_read_lock();
6631 for_each_domain(cpu, tmp) {
6632 if (!(tmp->flags & SD_LOAD_BALANCE))
6633 break;
6634
6635 /*
6636 * If both 'cpu' and 'prev_cpu' are part of this domain,
6637 * cpu is a valid SD_WAKE_AFFINE target.
6638 */
6639 if (want_affine && (tmp->flags & SD_WAKE_AFFINE) &&
6640 cpumask_test_cpu(prev_cpu, sched_domain_span(tmp))) {
6641 if (cpu != prev_cpu)
6642 new_cpu = wake_affine(tmp, p, cpu, prev_cpu, sync);
6643
6644 sd = NULL; /* Prefer wake_affine over balance flags */
6645 break;
6646 }
6647
6648 if (tmp->flags & sd_flag)
6649 sd = tmp;
6650 else if (!want_affine)
6651 break;
6652 }
6653
6654 if (unlikely(sd)) {
6655 /* Slow path */
6656 new_cpu = find_idlest_cpu(sd, p, cpu, prev_cpu, sd_flag);
6657 } else if (sd_flag & SD_BALANCE_WAKE) { /* XXX always ? */
6658 /* Fast path */
6659
6660 new_cpu = select_idle_sibling(p, prev_cpu, new_cpu);
6661
6662 if (want_affine)
6663 current->recent_used_cpu = cpu;
6664 }
6665 rcu_read_unlock();
6666
6667 return new_cpu;
6668}
6669
6670static void detach_entity_cfs_rq(struct sched_entity *se);
6671
6672/*
6673 * Called immediately before a task is migrated to a new CPU; task_cpu(p) and
6674 * cfs_rq_of(p) references at time of call are still valid and identify the
6675 * previous CPU. The caller guarantees p->pi_lock or task_rq(p)->lock is held.
6676 */
6677static void migrate_task_rq_fair(struct task_struct *p)
6678{
6679 /*
6680 * As blocked tasks retain absolute vruntime the migration needs to
6681 * deal with this by subtracting the old and adding the new
6682 * min_vruntime -- the latter is done by enqueue_entity() when placing
6683 * the task on the new runqueue.
6684 */
6685 if (p->state == TASK_WAKING) {
6686 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
6687 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
6688 u64 min_vruntime;
6689
6690#ifndef CONFIG_64BIT
6691 u64 min_vruntime_copy;
6692
6693 do {
6694 min_vruntime_copy = cfs_rq->min_vruntime_copy;
6695 smp_rmb();
6696 min_vruntime = cfs_rq->min_vruntime;
6697 } while (min_vruntime != min_vruntime_copy);
6698#else
6699 min_vruntime = cfs_rq->min_vruntime;
6700#endif
6701
6702 se->vruntime -= min_vruntime;
6703 }
6704
6705 if (p->on_rq == TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING) {
6706 /*
6707 * In case of TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING we in fact hold the 'old'
6708 * rq->lock and can modify state directly.
6709 */
6710 lockdep_assert_held(&task_rq(p)->lock);
6711 detach_entity_cfs_rq(&p->se);
6712
6713 } else {
6714 /*
6715 * We are supposed to update the task to "current" time, then
6716 * its up to date and ready to go to new CPU/cfs_rq. But we
6717 * have difficulty in getting what current time is, so simply
6718 * throw away the out-of-date time. This will result in the
6719 * wakee task is less decayed, but giving the wakee more load
6720 * sounds not bad.
6721 */
6722 remove_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6723 }
6724
6725 /* Tell new CPU we are migrated */
6726 p->se.avg.last_update_time = 0;
6727
6728 /* We have migrated, no longer consider this task hot */
6729 p->se.exec_start = 0;
6730}
6731
6732static void task_dead_fair(struct task_struct *p)
6733{
6734 remove_entity_load_avg(&p->se);
6735}
6736#endif /* CONFIG_SMP */
6737
6738static unsigned long wakeup_gran(struct sched_entity *se)
6739{
6740 unsigned long gran = sysctl_sched_wakeup_granularity;
6741
6742 /*
6743 * Since its curr running now, convert the gran from real-time
6744 * to virtual-time in his units.
6745 *
6746 * By using 'se' instead of 'curr' we penalize light tasks, so
6747 * they get preempted easier. That is, if 'se' < 'curr' then
6748 * the resulting gran will be larger, therefore penalizing the
6749 * lighter, if otoh 'se' > 'curr' then the resulting gran will
6750 * be smaller, again penalizing the lighter task.
6751 *
6752 * This is especially important for buddies when the leftmost
6753 * task is higher priority than the buddy.
6754 */
6755 return calc_delta_fair(gran, se);
6756}
6757
6758/*
6759 * Should 'se' preempt 'curr'.
6760 *
6761 * |s1
6762 * |s2
6763 * |s3
6764 * g
6765 * |<--->|c
6766 *
6767 * w(c, s1) = -1
6768 * w(c, s2) = 0
6769 * w(c, s3) = 1
6770 *
6771 */
6772static int
6773wakeup_preempt_entity(struct sched_entity *curr, struct sched_entity *se)
6774{
6775 s64 gran, vdiff = curr->vruntime - se->vruntime;
6776
6777 if (vdiff <= 0)
6778 return -1;
6779
6780 gran = wakeup_gran(se);
6781 if (vdiff > gran)
6782 return 1;
6783
6784 return 0;
6785}
6786
6787static void set_last_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
6788{
6789 if (entity_is_task(se) && unlikely(task_of(se)->policy == SCHED_IDLE))
6790 return;
6791
6792 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
6793 if (SCHED_WARN_ON(!se->on_rq))
6794 return;
6795 cfs_rq_of(se)->last = se;
6796 }
6797}
6798
6799static void set_next_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
6800{
6801 if (entity_is_task(se) && unlikely(task_of(se)->policy == SCHED_IDLE))
6802 return;
6803
6804 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
6805 if (SCHED_WARN_ON(!se->on_rq))
6806 return;
6807 cfs_rq_of(se)->next = se;
6808 }
6809}
6810
6811static void set_skip_buddy(struct sched_entity *se)
6812{
6813 for_each_sched_entity(se)
6814 cfs_rq_of(se)->skip = se;
6815}
6816
6817/*
6818 * Preempt the current task with a newly woken task if needed:
6819 */
6820static void check_preempt_wakeup(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, int wake_flags)
6821{
6822 struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
6823 struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se, *pse = &p->se;
6824 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(curr);
6825 int scale = cfs_rq->nr_running >= sched_nr_latency;
6826 int next_buddy_marked = 0;
6827
6828 if (unlikely(se == pse))
6829 return;
6830
6831 /*
6832 * This is possible from callers such as attach_tasks(), in which we
6833 * unconditionally check_prempt_curr() after an enqueue (which may have
6834 * lead to a throttle). This both saves work and prevents false
6835 * next-buddy nomination below.
6836 */
6837 if (unlikely(throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq_of(pse))))
6838 return;
6839
6840 if (sched_feat(NEXT_BUDDY) && scale && !(wake_flags & WF_FORK)) {
6841 set_next_buddy(pse);
6842 next_buddy_marked = 1;
6843 }
6844
6845 /*
6846 * We can come here with TIF_NEED_RESCHED already set from new task
6847 * wake up path.
6848 *
6849 * Note: this also catches the edge-case of curr being in a throttled
6850 * group (e.g. via set_curr_task), since update_curr() (in the
6851 * enqueue of curr) will have resulted in resched being set. This
6852 * prevents us from potentially nominating it as a false LAST_BUDDY
6853 * below.
6854 */
6855 if (test_tsk_need_resched(curr))
6856 return;
6857
6858 /* Idle tasks are by definition preempted by non-idle tasks. */
6859 if (unlikely(curr->policy == SCHED_IDLE) &&
6860 likely(p->policy != SCHED_IDLE))
6861 goto preempt;
6862
6863 /*
6864 * Batch and idle tasks do not preempt non-idle tasks (their preemption
6865 * is driven by the tick):
6866 */
6867 if (unlikely(p->policy != SCHED_NORMAL) || !sched_feat(WAKEUP_PREEMPTION))
6868 return;
6869
6870 find_matching_se(&se, &pse);
6871 update_curr(cfs_rq_of(se));
6872 BUG_ON(!pse);
6873 if (wakeup_preempt_entity(se, pse) == 1) {
6874 /*
6875 * Bias pick_next to pick the sched entity that is
6876 * triggering this preemption.
6877 */
6878 if (!next_buddy_marked)
6879 set_next_buddy(pse);
6880 goto preempt;
6881 }
6882
6883 return;
6884
6885preempt:
6886 resched_curr(rq);
6887 /*
6888 * Only set the backward buddy when the current task is still
6889 * on the rq. This can happen when a wakeup gets interleaved
6890 * with schedule on the ->pre_schedule() or idle_balance()
6891 * point, either of which can * drop the rq lock.
6892 *
6893 * Also, during early boot the idle thread is in the fair class,
6894 * for obvious reasons its a bad idea to schedule back to it.
6895 */
6896 if (unlikely(!se->on_rq || curr == rq->idle))
6897 return;
6898
6899 if (sched_feat(LAST_BUDDY) && scale && entity_is_task(se))
6900 set_last_buddy(se);
6901}
6902
6903static struct task_struct *
6904pick_next_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev, struct rq_flags *rf)
6905{
6906 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = &rq->cfs;
6907 struct sched_entity *se;
6908 struct task_struct *p;
6909 int new_tasks;
6910
6911again:
6912 if (!cfs_rq->nr_running)
6913 goto idle;
6914
6915#ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
6916 if (prev->sched_class != &fair_sched_class)
6917 goto simple;
6918
6919 /*
6920 * Because of the set_next_buddy() in dequeue_task_fair() it is rather
6921 * likely that a next task is from the same cgroup as the current.
6922 *
6923 * Therefore attempt to avoid putting and setting the entire cgroup
6924 * hierarchy, only change the part that actually changes.
6925 */
6926
6927 do {
6928 struct sched_entity *curr = cfs_rq->curr;
6929
6930 /*
6931 * Since we got here without doing put_prev_entity() we also
6932 * have to consider cfs_rq->curr. If it is still a runnable
6933 * entity, update_curr() will update its vruntime, otherwise
6934 * forget we've ever seen it.
6935 */
6936 if (curr) {
6937 if (curr->on_rq)
6938 update_curr(cfs_rq);
6939 else
6940 curr = NULL;
6941
6942 /*
6943 * This call to check_cfs_rq_runtime() will do the
6944 * throttle and dequeue its entity in the parent(s).
6945 * Therefore the nr_running test will indeed
6946 * be correct.
6947 */
6948 if (unlikely(check_cfs_rq_runtime(cfs_rq))) {
6949 cfs_rq = &rq->cfs;
6950
6951 if (!cfs_rq->nr_running)
6952 goto idle;
6953
6954 goto simple;
6955 }
6956 }
6957
6958 se = pick_next_entity(cfs_rq, curr);
6959 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
6960 } while (cfs_rq);
6961
6962 p = task_of(se);
6963
6964 /*
6965 * Since we haven't yet done put_prev_entity and if the selected task
6966 * is a different task than we started out with, try and touch the
6967 * least amount of cfs_rqs.
6968 */
6969 if (prev != p) {
6970 struct sched_entity *pse = &prev->se;
6971
6972 while (!(cfs_rq = is_same_group(se, pse))) {
6973 int se_depth = se->depth;
6974 int pse_depth = pse->depth;
6975
6976 if (se_depth <= pse_depth) {
6977 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq_of(pse), pse);
6978 pse = parent_entity(pse);
6979 }
6980 if (se_depth >= pse_depth) {
6981 set_next_entity(cfs_rq_of(se), se);
6982 se = parent_entity(se);
6983 }
6984 }
6985
6986 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq, pse);
6987 set_next_entity(cfs_rq, se);
6988 }
6989
6990 goto done;
6991simple:
6992#endif
6993
6994 put_prev_task(rq, prev);
6995
6996 do {
6997 se = pick_next_entity(cfs_rq, NULL);
6998 set_next_entity(cfs_rq, se);
6999 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
7000 } while (cfs_rq);
7001
7002 p = task_of(se);
7003
7004done: __maybe_unused;
7005#ifdef CONFIG_SMP
7006 /*
7007 * Move the next running task to the front of
7008 * the list, so our cfs_tasks list becomes MRU
7009 * one.
7010 */
7011 list_move(&p->se.group_node, &rq->cfs_tasks);
7012#endif
7013
7014 if (hrtick_enabled(rq))
7015 hrtick_start_fair(rq, p);
7016
7017 return p;
7018
7019idle:
7020 new_tasks = idle_balance(rq, rf);
7021
7022 /*
7023 * Because idle_balance() releases (and re-acquires) rq->lock, it is
7024 * possible for any higher priority task to appear. In that case we
7025 * must re-start the pick_next_entity() loop.
7026 */
7027 if (new_tasks < 0)
7028 return RETRY_TASK;
7029
7030 if (new_tasks > 0)
7031 goto again;
7032
7033 return NULL;
7034}
7035
7036/*
7037 * Account for a descheduled task:
7038 */
7039static void put_prev_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *prev)
7040{
7041 struct sched_entity *se = &prev->se;
7042 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq;
7043
7044 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
7045 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
7046 put_prev_entity(cfs_rq, se);
7047 }
7048}
7049
7050/*
7051 * sched_yield() is very simple
7052 *
7053 * The magic of dealing with the ->skip buddy is in pick_next_entity.
7054 */
7055static void yield_task_fair(struct rq *rq)
7056{
7057 struct task_struct *curr = rq->curr;
7058 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(curr);
7059 struct sched_entity *se = &curr->se;
7060
7061 /*
7062 * Are we the only task in the tree?
7063 */
7064 if (unlikely(rq->nr_running == 1))
7065 return;
7066
7067 clear_buddies(cfs_rq, se);
7068
7069 if (curr->policy != SCHED_BATCH) {
7070 update_rq_clock(rq);
7071 /*
7072 * Update run-time statistics of the 'current'.
7073 */
7074 update_curr(cfs_rq);
7075 /*
7076 * Tell update_rq_clock() that we've just updated,
7077 * so we don't do microscopic update in schedule()
7078 * and double the fastpath cost.
7079 */
7080 rq_clock_skip_update(rq);
7081 }
7082
7083 set_skip_buddy(se);
7084}
7085
7086static bool yield_to_task_fair(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p, bool preempt)
7087{
7088 struct sched_entity *se = &p->se;
7089
7090 /* throttled hierarchies are not runnable */
7091 if (!se->on_rq || throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq_of(se)))
7092 return false;
7093
7094 /* Tell the scheduler that we'd really like pse to run next. */
7095 set_next_buddy(se);
7096
7097 yield_task_fair(rq);
7098
7099 return true;
7100}
7101
7102#ifdef CONFIG_SMP
7103/**************************************************
7104 * Fair scheduling class load-balancing methods.
7105 *
7106 * BASICS
7107 *
7108 * The purpose of load-balancing is to achieve the same basic fairness the
7109 * per-CPU scheduler provides, namely provide a proportional amount of compute
7110 * time to each task. This is expressed in the following equation:
7111 *
7112 * W_i,n/P_i == W_j,n/P_j for all i,j (1)
7113 *
7114 * Where W_i,n is the n-th weight average for CPU i. The instantaneous weight
7115 * W_i,0 is defined as:
7116 *
7117 * W_i,0 = \Sum_j w_i,j (2)
7118 *
7119 * Where w_i,j is the weight of the j-th runnable task on CPU i. This weight
7120 * is derived from the nice value as per sched_prio_to_weight[].
7121 *
7122 * The weight average is an exponential decay average of the instantaneous
7123 * weight:
7124 *
7125 * W'_i,n = (2^n - 1) / 2^n * W_i,n + 1 / 2^n * W_i,0 (3)
7126 *
7127 * C_i is the compute capacity of CPU i, typically it is the
7128 * fraction of 'recent' time available for SCHED_OTHER task execution. But it
7129 * can also include other factors [XXX].
7130 *
7131 * To achieve this balance we define a measure of imbalance which follows
7132 * directly from (1):
7133 *
7134 * imb_i,j = max{ avg(W/C), W_i/C_i } - min{ avg(W/C), W_j/C_j } (4)
7135 *
7136 * We them move tasks around to minimize the imbalance. In the continuous
7137 * function space it is obvious this converges, in the discrete case we get
7138 * a few fun cases generally called infeasible weight scenarios.
7139 *
7140 * [XXX expand on:
7141 * - infeasible weights;
7142 * - local vs global optima in the discrete case. ]
7143 *
7144 *
7145 * SCHED DOMAINS
7146 *
7147 * In order to solve the imbalance equation (4), and avoid the obvious O(n^2)
7148 * for all i,j solution, we create a tree of CPUs that follows the hardware
7149 * topology where each level pairs two lower groups (or better). This results
7150 * in O(log n) layers. Furthermore we reduce the number of CPUs going up the
7151 * tree to only the first of the previous level and we decrease the frequency
7152 * of load-balance at each level inv. proportional to the number of CPUs in
7153 * the groups.
7154 *
7155 * This yields:
7156 *
7157 * log_2 n 1 n
7158 * \Sum { --- * --- * 2^i } = O(n) (5)
7159 * i = 0 2^i 2^i
7160 * `- size of each group
7161 * | | `- number of CPUs doing load-balance
7162 * | `- freq
7163 * `- sum over all levels
7164 *
7165 * Coupled with a limit on how many tasks we can migrate every balance pass,
7166 * this makes (5) the runtime complexity of the balancer.
7167 *
7168 * An important property here is that each CPU is still (indirectly) connected
7169 * to every other CPU in at most O(log n) steps:
7170 *
7171 * The adjacency matrix of the resulting graph is given by:
7172 *
7173 * log_2 n
7174 * A_i,j = \Union (i % 2^k == 0) && i / 2^(k+1) == j / 2^(k+1) (6)
7175 * k = 0
7176 *
7177 * And you'll find that:
7178 *
7179 * A^(log_2 n)_i,j != 0 for all i,j (7)
7180 *
7181 * Showing there's indeed a path between every CPU in at most O(log n) steps.
7182 * The task movement gives a factor of O(m), giving a convergence complexity
7183 * of:
7184 *
7185 * O(nm log n), n := nr_cpus, m := nr_tasks (8)
7186 *
7187 *
7188 * WORK CONSERVING
7189 *
7190 * In order to avoid CPUs going idle while there's still work to do, new idle
7191 * balancing is more aggressive and has the newly idle CPU iterate up the domain
7192 * tree itself instead of relying on other CPUs to bring it work.
7193 *
7194 * This adds some complexity to both (5) and (8) but it reduces the total idle
7195 * time.
7196 *
7197 * [XXX more?]
7198 *
7199 *
7200 * CGROUPS
7201 *
7202 * Cgroups make a horror show out of (2), instead of a simple sum we get:
7203 *
7204 * s_k,i
7205 * W_i,0 = \Sum_j \Prod_k w_k * ----- (9)
7206 * S_k
7207 *
7208 * Where
7209 *
7210 * s_k,i = \Sum_j w_i,j,k and S_k = \Sum_i s_k,i (10)
7211 *
7212 * w_i,j,k is the weight of the j-th runnable task in the k-th cgroup on CPU i.
7213 *
7214 * The big problem is S_k, its a global sum needed to compute a local (W_i)
7215 * property.
7216 *
7217 * [XXX write more on how we solve this.. _after_ merging pjt's patches that
7218 * rewrite all of this once again.]
7219 */
7220
7221static unsigned long __read_mostly max_load_balance_interval = HZ/10;
7222
7223enum fbq_type { regular, remote, all };
7224
7225#define LBF_ALL_PINNED 0x01
7226#define LBF_NEED_BREAK 0x02
7227#define LBF_DST_PINNED 0x04
7228#define LBF_SOME_PINNED 0x08
7229#define LBF_NOHZ_STATS 0x10
7230#define LBF_NOHZ_AGAIN 0x20
7231
7232struct lb_env {
7233 struct sched_domain *sd;
7234
7235 struct rq *src_rq;
7236 int src_cpu;
7237
7238 int dst_cpu;
7239 struct rq *dst_rq;
7240
7241 struct cpumask *dst_grpmask;
7242 int new_dst_cpu;
7243 enum cpu_idle_type idle;
7244 long imbalance;
7245 /* The set of CPUs under consideration for load-balancing */
7246 struct cpumask *cpus;
7247
7248 unsigned int flags;
7249
7250 unsigned int loop;
7251 unsigned int loop_break;
7252 unsigned int loop_max;
7253
7254 enum fbq_type fbq_type;
7255 struct list_head tasks;
7256};
7257
7258/*
7259 * Is this task likely cache-hot:
7260 */
7261static int task_hot(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
7262{
7263 s64 delta;
7264
7265 lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7266
7267 if (p->sched_class != &fair_sched_class)
7268 return 0;
7269
7270 if (unlikely(p->policy == SCHED_IDLE))
7271 return 0;
7272
7273 /*
7274 * Buddy candidates are cache hot:
7275 */
7276 if (sched_feat(CACHE_HOT_BUDDY) && env->dst_rq->nr_running &&
7277 (&p->se == cfs_rq_of(&p->se)->next ||
7278 &p->se == cfs_rq_of(&p->se)->last))
7279 return 1;
7280
7281 if (sysctl_sched_migration_cost == -1)
7282 return 1;
7283 if (sysctl_sched_migration_cost == 0)
7284 return 0;
7285
7286 delta = rq_clock_task(env->src_rq) - p->se.exec_start;
7287
7288 return delta < (s64)sysctl_sched_migration_cost;
7289}
7290
7291#ifdef CONFIG_NUMA_BALANCING
7292/*
7293 * Returns 1, if task migration degrades locality
7294 * Returns 0, if task migration improves locality i.e migration preferred.
7295 * Returns -1, if task migration is not affected by locality.
7296 */
7297static int migrate_degrades_locality(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
7298{
7299 struct numa_group *numa_group = rcu_dereference(p->numa_group);
7300 unsigned long src_faults, dst_faults;
7301 int src_nid, dst_nid;
7302
7303 if (!static_branch_likely(&sched_numa_balancing))
7304 return -1;
7305
7306 if (!p->numa_faults || !(env->sd->flags & SD_NUMA))
7307 return -1;
7308
7309 src_nid = cpu_to_node(env->src_cpu);
7310 dst_nid = cpu_to_node(env->dst_cpu);
7311
7312 if (src_nid == dst_nid)
7313 return -1;
7314
7315 /* Migrating away from the preferred node is always bad. */
7316 if (src_nid == p->numa_preferred_nid) {
7317 if (env->src_rq->nr_running > env->src_rq->nr_preferred_running)
7318 return 1;
7319 else
7320 return -1;
7321 }
7322
7323 /* Encourage migration to the preferred node. */
7324 if (dst_nid == p->numa_preferred_nid)
7325 return 0;
7326
7327 /* Leaving a core idle is often worse than degrading locality. */
7328 if (env->idle != CPU_NOT_IDLE)
7329 return -1;
7330
7331 if (numa_group) {
7332 src_faults = group_faults(p, src_nid);
7333 dst_faults = group_faults(p, dst_nid);
7334 } else {
7335 src_faults = task_faults(p, src_nid);
7336 dst_faults = task_faults(p, dst_nid);
7337 }
7338
7339 return dst_faults < src_faults;
7340}
7341
7342#else
7343static inline int migrate_degrades_locality(struct task_struct *p,
7344 struct lb_env *env)
7345{
7346 return -1;
7347}
7348#endif
7349
7350/*
7351 * can_migrate_task - may task p from runqueue rq be migrated to this_cpu?
7352 */
7353static
7354int can_migrate_task(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
7355{
7356 int tsk_cache_hot;
7357
7358 lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7359
7360 /*
7361 * We do not migrate tasks that are:
7362 * 1) throttled_lb_pair, or
7363 * 2) cannot be migrated to this CPU due to cpus_allowed, or
7364 * 3) running (obviously), or
7365 * 4) are cache-hot on their current CPU.
7366 */
7367 if (throttled_lb_pair(task_group(p), env->src_cpu, env->dst_cpu))
7368 return 0;
7369
7370 if (!cpumask_test_cpu(env->dst_cpu, &p->cpus_allowed)) {
7371 int cpu;
7372
7373 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_affine);
7374
7375 env->flags |= LBF_SOME_PINNED;
7376
7377 /*
7378 * Remember if this task can be migrated to any other CPU in
7379 * our sched_group. We may want to revisit it if we couldn't
7380 * meet load balance goals by pulling other tasks on src_cpu.
7381 *
7382 * Avoid computing new_dst_cpu for NEWLY_IDLE or if we have
7383 * already computed one in current iteration.
7384 */
7385 if (env->idle == CPU_NEWLY_IDLE || (env->flags & LBF_DST_PINNED))
7386 return 0;
7387
7388 /* Prevent to re-select dst_cpu via env's CPUs: */
7389 for_each_cpu_and(cpu, env->dst_grpmask, env->cpus) {
7390 if (cpumask_test_cpu(cpu, &p->cpus_allowed)) {
7391 env->flags |= LBF_DST_PINNED;
7392 env->new_dst_cpu = cpu;
7393 break;
7394 }
7395 }
7396
7397 return 0;
7398 }
7399
7400 /* Record that we found atleast one task that could run on dst_cpu */
7401 env->flags &= ~LBF_ALL_PINNED;
7402
7403 if (task_running(env->src_rq, p)) {
7404 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_running);
7405 return 0;
7406 }
7407
7408 /*
7409 * Aggressive migration if:
7410 * 1) destination numa is preferred
7411 * 2) task is cache cold, or
7412 * 3) too many balance attempts have failed.
7413 */
7414 tsk_cache_hot = migrate_degrades_locality(p, env);
7415 if (tsk_cache_hot == -1)
7416 tsk_cache_hot = task_hot(p, env);
7417
7418 if (tsk_cache_hot <= 0 ||
7419 env->sd->nr_balance_failed > env->sd->cache_nice_tries) {
7420 if (tsk_cache_hot == 1) {
7421 schedstat_inc(env->sd->lb_hot_gained[env->idle]);
7422 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_forced_migrations);
7423 }
7424 return 1;
7425 }
7426
7427 schedstat_inc(p->se.statistics.nr_failed_migrations_hot);
7428 return 0;
7429}
7430
7431/*
7432 * detach_task() -- detach the task for the migration specified in env
7433 */
7434static void detach_task(struct task_struct *p, struct lb_env *env)
7435{
7436 lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7437
7438 p->on_rq = TASK_ON_RQ_MIGRATING;
7439 deactivate_task(env->src_rq, p, DEQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
7440 set_task_cpu(p, env->dst_cpu);
7441}
7442
7443/*
7444 * detach_one_task() -- tries to dequeue exactly one task from env->src_rq, as
7445 * part of active balancing operations within "domain".
7446 *
7447 * Returns a task if successful and NULL otherwise.
7448 */
7449static struct task_struct *detach_one_task(struct lb_env *env)
7450{
7451 struct task_struct *p;
7452
7453 lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7454
7455 list_for_each_entry_reverse(p,
7456 &env->src_rq->cfs_tasks, se.group_node) {
7457 if (!can_migrate_task(p, env))
7458 continue;
7459
7460 detach_task(p, env);
7461
7462 /*
7463 * Right now, this is only the second place where
7464 * lb_gained[env->idle] is updated (other is detach_tasks)
7465 * so we can safely collect stats here rather than
7466 * inside detach_tasks().
7467 */
7468 schedstat_inc(env->sd->lb_gained[env->idle]);
7469 return p;
7470 }
7471 return NULL;
7472}
7473
7474static const unsigned int sched_nr_migrate_break = 32;
7475
7476/*
7477 * detach_tasks() -- tries to detach up to imbalance weighted load from
7478 * busiest_rq, as part of a balancing operation within domain "sd".
7479 *
7480 * Returns number of detached tasks if successful and 0 otherwise.
7481 */
7482static int detach_tasks(struct lb_env *env)
7483{
7484 struct list_head *tasks = &env->src_rq->cfs_tasks;
7485 struct task_struct *p;
7486 unsigned long load;
7487 int detached = 0;
7488
7489 lockdep_assert_held(&env->src_rq->lock);
7490
7491 if (env->imbalance <= 0)
7492 return 0;
7493
7494 while (!list_empty(tasks)) {
7495 /*
7496 * We don't want to steal all, otherwise we may be treated likewise,
7497 * which could at worst lead to a livelock crash.
7498 */
7499 if (env->idle != CPU_NOT_IDLE && env->src_rq->nr_running <= 1)
7500 break;
7501
7502 p = list_last_entry(tasks, struct task_struct, se.group_node);
7503
7504 env->loop++;
7505 /* We've more or less seen every task there is, call it quits */
7506 if (env->loop > env->loop_max)
7507 break;
7508
7509 /* take a breather every nr_migrate tasks */
7510 if (env->loop > env->loop_break) {
7511 env->loop_break += sched_nr_migrate_break;
7512 env->flags |= LBF_NEED_BREAK;
7513 break;
7514 }
7515
7516 if (!can_migrate_task(p, env))
7517 goto next;
7518
7519 load = task_h_load(p);
7520
7521 if (sched_feat(LB_MIN) && load < 16 && !env->sd->nr_balance_failed)
7522 goto next;
7523
7524 if ((load / 2) > env->imbalance)
7525 goto next;
7526
7527 detach_task(p, env);
7528 list_add(&p->se.group_node, &env->tasks);
7529
7530 detached++;
7531 env->imbalance -= load;
7532
7533#ifdef CONFIG_PREEMPT
7534 /*
7535 * NEWIDLE balancing is a source of latency, so preemptible
7536 * kernels will stop after the first task is detached to minimize
7537 * the critical section.
7538 */
7539 if (env->idle == CPU_NEWLY_IDLE)
7540 break;
7541#endif
7542
7543 /*
7544 * We only want to steal up to the prescribed amount of
7545 * weighted load.
7546 */
7547 if (env->imbalance <= 0)
7548 break;
7549
7550 continue;
7551next:
7552 list_move(&p->se.group_node, tasks);
7553 }
7554
7555 /*
7556 * Right now, this is one of only two places we collect this stat
7557 * so we can safely collect detach_one_task() stats here rather
7558 * than inside detach_one_task().
7559 */
7560 schedstat_add(env->sd->lb_gained[env->idle], detached);
7561
7562 return detached;
7563}
7564
7565/*
7566 * attach_task() -- attach the task detached by detach_task() to its new rq.
7567 */
7568static void attach_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
7569{
7570 lockdep_assert_held(&rq->lock);
7571
7572 BUG_ON(task_rq(p) != rq);
7573 activate_task(rq, p, ENQUEUE_NOCLOCK);
7574 p->on_rq = TASK_ON_RQ_QUEUED;
7575 check_preempt_curr(rq, p, 0);
7576}
7577
7578/*
7579 * attach_one_task() -- attaches the task returned from detach_one_task() to
7580 * its new rq.
7581 */
7582static void attach_one_task(struct rq *rq, struct task_struct *p)
7583{
7584 struct rq_flags rf;
7585
7586 rq_lock(rq, &rf);
7587 update_rq_clock(rq);
7588 attach_task(rq, p);
7589 rq_unlock(rq, &rf);
7590}
7591
7592/*
7593 * attach_tasks() -- attaches all tasks detached by detach_tasks() to their
7594 * new rq.
7595 */
7596static void attach_tasks(struct lb_env *env)
7597{
7598 struct list_head *tasks = &env->tasks;
7599 struct task_struct *p;
7600 struct rq_flags rf;
7601
7602 rq_lock(env->dst_rq, &rf);
7603 update_rq_clock(env->dst_rq);
7604
7605 while (!list_empty(tasks)) {
7606 p = list_first_entry(tasks, struct task_struct, se.group_node);
7607 list_del_init(&p->se.group_node);
7608
7609 attach_task(env->dst_rq, p);
7610 }
7611
7612 rq_unlock(env->dst_rq, &rf);
7613}
7614
7615static inline bool cfs_rq_has_blocked(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
7616{
7617 if (cfs_rq->avg.load_avg)
7618 return true;
7619
7620 if (cfs_rq->avg.util_avg)
7621 return true;
7622
7623 return false;
7624}
7625
7626#ifdef CONFIG_FAIR_GROUP_SCHED
7627
7628static inline bool cfs_rq_is_decayed(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
7629{
7630 if (cfs_rq->load.weight)
7631 return false;
7632
7633 if (cfs_rq->avg.load_sum)
7634 return false;
7635
7636 if (cfs_rq->avg.util_sum)
7637 return false;
7638
7639 if (cfs_rq->avg.runnable_load_sum)
7640 return false;
7641
7642 return true;
7643}
7644
7645static void update_blocked_averages(int cpu)
7646{
7647 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
7648 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq, *pos;
7649 struct rq_flags rf;
7650 bool done = true;
7651
7652 rq_lock_irqsave(rq, &rf);
7653 update_rq_clock(rq);
7654
7655 /*
7656 * Iterates the task_group tree in a bottom up fashion, see
7657 * list_add_leaf_cfs_rq() for details.
7658 */
7659 for_each_leaf_cfs_rq_safe(rq, cfs_rq, pos) {
7660 struct sched_entity *se;
7661
7662 /* throttled entities do not contribute to load */
7663 if (throttled_hierarchy(cfs_rq))
7664 continue;
7665
7666 if (update_cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq_clock_task(cfs_rq), cfs_rq))
7667 update_tg_load_avg(cfs_rq, 0);
7668
7669 /* Propagate pending load changes to the parent, if any: */
7670 se = cfs_rq->tg->se[cpu];
7671 if (se && !skip_blocked_update(se))
7672 update_load_avg(cfs_rq_of(se), se, 0);
7673
7674 /*
7675 * There can be a lot of idle CPU cgroups. Don't let fully
7676 * decayed cfs_rqs linger on the list.
7677 */
7678 if (cfs_rq_is_decayed(cfs_rq))
7679 list_del_leaf_cfs_rq(cfs_rq);
7680
7681 /* Don't need periodic decay once load/util_avg are null */
7682 if (cfs_rq_has_blocked(cfs_rq))
7683 done = false;
7684 }
7685
7686#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
7687 rq->last_blocked_load_update_tick = jiffies;
7688 if (done)
7689 rq->has_blocked_load = 0;
7690#endif
7691 rq_unlock_irqrestore(rq, &rf);
7692}
7693
7694/*
7695 * Compute the hierarchical load factor for cfs_rq and all its ascendants.
7696 * This needs to be done in a top-down fashion because the load of a child
7697 * group is a fraction of its parents load.
7698 */
7699static void update_cfs_rq_h_load(struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq)
7700{
7701 struct rq *rq = rq_of(cfs_rq);
7702 struct sched_entity *se = cfs_rq->tg->se[cpu_of(rq)];
7703 unsigned long now = jiffies;
7704 unsigned long load;
7705
7706 if (cfs_rq->last_h_load_update == now)
7707 return;
7708
7709 cfs_rq->h_load_next = NULL;
7710 for_each_sched_entity(se) {
7711 cfs_rq = cfs_rq_of(se);
7712 cfs_rq->h_load_next = se;
7713 if (cfs_rq->last_h_load_update == now)
7714 break;
7715 }
7716
7717 if (!se) {
7718 cfs_rq->h_load = cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq);
7719 cfs_rq->last_h_load_update = now;
7720 }
7721
7722 while ((se = cfs_rq->h_load_next) != NULL) {
7723 load = cfs_rq->h_load;
7724 load = div64_ul(load * se->avg.load_avg,
7725 cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq) + 1);
7726 cfs_rq = group_cfs_rq(se);
7727 cfs_rq->h_load = load;
7728 cfs_rq->last_h_load_update = now;
7729 }
7730}
7731
7732static unsigned long task_h_load(struct task_struct *p)
7733{
7734 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = task_cfs_rq(p);
7735
7736 update_cfs_rq_h_load(cfs_rq);
7737 return div64_ul(p->se.avg.load_avg * cfs_rq->h_load,
7738 cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq) + 1);
7739}
7740#else
7741static inline void update_blocked_averages(int cpu)
7742{
7743 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
7744 struct cfs_rq *cfs_rq = &rq->cfs;
7745 struct rq_flags rf;
7746
7747 rq_lock_irqsave(rq, &rf);
7748 update_rq_clock(rq);
7749 update_cfs_rq_load_avg(cfs_rq_clock_task(cfs_rq), cfs_rq);
7750#ifdef CONFIG_NO_HZ_COMMON
7751 rq->last_blocked_load_update_tick = jiffies;
7752 if (!cfs_rq_has_blocked(cfs_rq))
7753 rq->has_blocked_load = 0;
7754#endif
7755 rq_unlock_irqrestore(rq, &rf);
7756}
7757
7758static unsigned long task_h_load(struct task_struct *p)
7759{
7760 return p->se.avg.load_avg;
7761}
7762#endif
7763
7764/********** Helpers for find_busiest_group ************************/
7765
7766enum group_type {
7767 group_other = 0,
7768 group_imbalanced,
7769 group_overloaded,
7770};
7771
7772/*
7773 * sg_lb_stats - stats of a sched_group required for load_balancing
7774 */
7775struct sg_lb_stats {
7776 unsigned long avg_load; /*Avg load across the CPUs of the group */
7777 unsigned long group_load; /* Total load over the CPUs of the group */
7778 unsigned long sum_weighted_load; /* Weighted load of group's tasks */
7779 unsigned long load_per_task;
7780 unsigned long group_capacity;
7781 unsigned long group_util; /* Total utilization of the group */
7782 unsigned int sum_nr_running; /* Nr tasks running in the group */
7783 unsigned int idle_cpus;
7784 unsigned int group_weight;
7785 enum group_type group_type;
7786 int group_no_capacity;
7787#ifdef CONFIG_NUMA_BALANCING
7788 unsigned int nr_numa_running;
7789 unsigned int nr_preferred_running;
7790#endif
7791};
7792
7793/*
7794 * sd_lb_stats - Structure to store the statistics of a sched_domain
7795 * during load balancing.
7796 */
7797struct sd_lb_stats {
7798 struct sched_group *busiest; /* Busiest group in this sd */
7799 struct sched_group *local; /* Local group in this sd */
7800 unsigned long total_running;
7801 unsigned long total_load; /* Total load of all groups in sd */
7802 unsigned long total_capacity; /* Total capacity of all groups in sd */
7803 unsigned long avg_load; /* Average load across all groups in sd */
7804
7805 struct sg_lb_stats busiest_stat;/* Statistics of the busiest group */
7806 struct sg_lb_stats local_stat; /* Statistics of the local group */
7807};
7808
7809static inline void init_sd_lb_stats(struct sd_lb_stats *sds)
7810{
7811 /*
7812 * Skimp on the clearing to avoid duplicate work. We can avoid clearing
7813 * local_stat because update_sg_lb_stats() does a full clear/assignment.
7814 * We must however clear busiest_stat::avg_load because
7815 * update_sd_pick_busiest() reads this before assignment.
7816 */
7817 *sds = (struct sd_lb_stats){
7818 .busiest = NULL,
7819 .local = NULL,
7820 .total_running = 0UL,
7821 .total_load = 0UL,
7822 .total_capacity = 0UL,
7823 .busiest_stat = {
7824 .avg_load = 0UL,
7825 .sum_nr_running = 0,
7826 .group_type = group_other,
7827 },
7828 };
7829}
7830
7831/**
7832 * get_sd_load_idx - Obtain the load index for a given sched domain.
7833 * @sd: The sched_domain whose load_idx is to be obtained.
7834 * @idle: The idle status of the CPU for whose sd load_idx is obtained.
7835 *
7836 * Return: The load index.
7837 */
7838static inline int get_sd_load_idx(struct sched_domain *sd,
7839 enum cpu_idle_type idle)
7840{
7841 int load_idx;
7842
7843 switch (idle) {
7844 case CPU_NOT_IDLE:
7845 load_idx = sd->busy_idx;
7846 break;
7847
7848 case CPU_NEWLY_IDLE:
7849 load_idx = sd->newidle_idx;
7850 break;
7851 default:
7852 load_idx = sd->idle_idx;
7853 break;
7854 }
7855
7856 return load_idx;
7857}
7858
7859static unsigned long scale_rt_capacity(int cpu)
7860{
7861 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
7862 u64 total, used, age_stamp, avg;
7863 s64 delta;
7864
7865 /*
7866 * Since we're reading these variables without serialization make sure
7867 * we read them once before doing sanity checks on them.
7868 */
7869 age_stamp = READ_ONCE(rq->age_stamp);
7870 avg = READ_ONCE(rq->rt_avg);
7871 delta = __rq_clock_broken(rq) - age_stamp;
7872
7873 if (unlikely(delta < 0))
7874 delta = 0;
7875
7876 total = sched_avg_period() + delta;
7877
7878 used = div_u64(avg, total);
7879
7880 if (likely(used < SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE))
7881 return SCHED_CAPACITY_SCALE - used;
7882
7883 return 1;
7884}
7885
7886static void update_cpu_capacity(struct sched_domain *sd, int cpu)
7887{
7888 unsigned long capacity = arch_scale_cpu_capacity(sd, cpu);
7889 struct sched_group *sdg = sd->groups;
7890
7891 cpu_rq(cpu)->cpu_capacity_orig = capacity;
7892
7893 capacity *= scale_rt_capacity(cpu);
7894 capacity >>= SCHED_CAPACITY_SHIFT;
7895
7896 if (!capacity)
7897 capacity = 1;
7898
7899 cpu_rq(cpu)->cpu_capacity = capacity;
7900 sdg->sgc->capacity = capacity;
7901 sdg->sgc->min_capacity = capacity;
7902}
7903
7904void update_group_capacity(struct sched_domain *sd, int cpu)
7905{
7906 struct sched_domain *child = sd->child;
7907 struct sched_group *group, *sdg = sd->groups;
7908 unsigned long capacity, min_capacity;
7909 unsigned long interval;
7910
7911 interval = msecs_to_jiffies(sd->balance_interval);
7912 interval = clamp(interval, 1UL, max_load_balance_interval);
7913 sdg->sgc->next_update = jiffies + interval;
7914
7915 if (!child) {
7916 update_cpu_capacity(sd, cpu);
7917 return;
7918 }
7919
7920 capacity = 0;
7921 min_capacity = ULONG_MAX;
7922
7923 if (child->flags & SD_OVERLAP) {
7924 /*
7925 * SD_OVERLAP domains cannot assume that child groups
7926 * span the current group.
7927 */
7928
7929 for_each_cpu(cpu, sched_group_span(sdg)) {
7930 struct sched_group_capacity *sgc;
7931 struct rq *rq = cpu_rq(cpu);
7932
7933 /*
7934 * build_sched_domains() -> init_sched_groups_capacity()
7935 * gets here before we've attached the domains to the
7936 * runqueues.
7937 *
7938 * Use capacity_of(), which is set irrespective of domains
7939 * in update_cpu_capacity().
7940 *
7941 * This avoids capacity from being 0 and
7942 * causing divide-by-zero issues on boot.
7943 */
7944 if (unlikely(!rq->sd)) {
7945 capacity += capacity_of(cpu);
7946 } else {
7947 sgc = rq->sd->groups->sgc;
7948 capacity += sgc->capacity;
7949 }
7950
